title-group.article-title: Symbiosis-related genes sustain the development of a downy mildew pathogen on Arabidopsis thaliana

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The interfaces through which nutrients are transferred from plant cells to arbuscular mycorrhiza fungi and biotrophic hyphal pathogens are structurally similar. We report that in Arabidopsis thaliana, mutations in homologs of common symbiosis genes (CSGs) encoding homologs of the symbiosis receptor kinase SYMRK, the nucleoporins NUP133 and SEC13 or the cation channel POLLUX reduce the reproductive success of Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis (Hpa). Analysis of the multiplication of extracellular bacterial pathogens, Hpa-induced cell death or callose accumulation, as well as Hpa-or flg22-induced defence marker gene expression, did not reveal any traces of constitutive or exacerbated defence responses. We discovered an age-dependent, possibly senescence-related transition of haustorial shape that occurred significantly earlier and at higher frequency in the CSG mutants. These findings point to a function of the homologs of common symbiosis genes in haustorial maintenance thus revealing an overlapping gene set for the intracellular accommodation of hyphal symbionts and pathogens.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Most land plant species feed carbon sources to arbuscular mycorrhiza (AM) fungi, which in turn deliver phosphate and other nutrients via finely branched intracellular structures called arbuscules (Gutjahr and Parniske, 2013, Gutjahr, 2014). The accommodation of fungal symbionts inside living plant cells involves substantial developmental reprogramming of the host plant cell, initiated by the formation of the pre-penetration apparatus, a transvacuolar cytoplasmic bridge formed in anticipation of fungal infection (Genre et al., 2005, Genre et al., 2008). The oomycetal downy mildew pathogen Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis (Hpa) develops intracellular feeding organs, so called haustoria, which exhibit structural similarities to the arbuscules of AM fungi. Like arbuscules, haustoria are accommodated inside plant cells and are entirely surrounded by a plant-derived membrane, which keeps the pathogen physically outside the host cytoplasm (Mims et al., 2002, Pumplin and Harrison, 2009, Hückelhoven and Panstruga, 2011). Structural and functional similarities between accommodation structures for intracellular microbes raised the hypothesis that the corresponding symbiotic and pathogenic associations rely on a shared genetic program (Parniske, 2000). This would imply that filamentous hyphal pathogens exploit an Achilles heel, the presence of the symbiotic program in most land plant species, for their own parasitic lifestyle (Parniske, 2000, Evangelisti et al., 2014).

In the present study, we tested this hypothesis by focussing on an ancient genetic program comprising the common symbiosis genes (CSGs), which is conserved among angiosperms for the intracellular accommodation of AM fungi (Stracke et al., 2002, Endre et al., 2002, Imaizumi-Anruko et al., 2004, Ané et al., 2004, Levy et al., 2004, Mitra et al., 2004, Kistner et al., 2005, Saito et al., 2007, Yano et al., 2008, Banba et al., 2008, Groth et al., 2010). In legumes and Actinorhiza host plants, the CSGs are also required for root nodule symbiosis (RNS) with nitrogen-fixing rhizobia or Frankia bacteria, respectively (Kistner et al., 2005, Markmann et al., 2008, Gherbi et al., 2008, Svistoonoff et al., 2013). In the legume Lotus japonicus, the products of some of the CSGs - the malectin-like domain leucine-rich repeat receptor-like kinase (MLD-LRR-RLK) Symbiosis Receptor-like Kinase SYMRK (Stracke et al., 2002, Markmann et al., 2008, Antolin-Llovera et al., 2014, Ried et al., 2014), the nucleoporins NUP85, NUP133 and SEC13 homolog (SEH1) of the NUP107-160 subcomplex (Kanamori et al., 2006, Alber et al., 2007, Saito et al., 2007, Groth et al., 2010), as well as the nuclear-envelope localised cation channel POLLUX (Charpentier et al., 2008, Venkateshwaran et al., 2012) - are implicated in a signal transduction pathway leading from the perception of microbial signalling molecules at the plasma membrane to the induction of calcium oscillations in and around the nucleus (calcium-spiking), which finally results in the activation of symbiosis-related genes and a developmental reprogramming of the respective host cells (Gutjahr and Parniske, 2013, Oldroyd, 2013).

Arabidopsis thaliana belongs to the Brassicaceae, a plant lineage that lost the ability to establish AM symbiosis after the divergence of the Brassicales (Favre et al., 2014, Delaux et al., 2014, Bravo et al., 2016). This asymbiotic state correlates with the loss of specific CSGs encoding e.g. the nuclear calcium-spiking decoder complex consisting of the calcium and calmodulin-depended protein kinase CCaMK and its phosphorylation target CYCLOPS, which is of central importance for transcriptional regulation in symbioses (Singh and Parniske, 2012, Singh et al., 2014, Favre et al., 2014, Bravo et al., 2016, Pimprikar et al., 2016, Cerri et al., 2017). These findings suggest a strong selection for the genome-wide loss of symbiosis-related genes. A. thaliana can, however, establish a compatible interaction with Hpa, and besides the loss of certain CSGs, retained homologs of other CSGs in its genome. The retention of these CSGs in the A. thaliana genome, as well as the striking similarities between arbuscules and haustoria led us to investigate whether this vestigial symbiotic gene set plays a role in the interaction of A. thaliana with Hpa, the fungal powdery mildew pathogen Erysiphe cruciferarum, which forms intracellular haustoria in A. thaliana epidermal leaf cells, or the extracellular bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We inspected the A. thaliana genome for the presence of CSGs and identified candidate orthologs of POLLUX and of nucleoporin genes of the NUP107-160 subcomplex (Figure 1 – Figure Supplement 1 + 2). Even though a direct ortholog of SYMRK has been deleted from the A. thaliana genome (Kevei et al., 2005), the products of two A. thaliana genes, which we consequently named SYMRK-homologous Receptor-like Kinase 1 (ShRK1) and ShRK2, were identified as the close relatives of LjSYMRK ((Markmann et al., 2008); Figure 1- Figure Supplement 1 - 4).

Lines carrying insertional mutant alleles of these CSGs were analysed for their phenotype in the interaction with Hpa. In pollux, shrk1, shrk2, the shrk1 x shrk2 double mutant, as well as a reference line with a T-DNA insertion in Phytosulfokine Receptor 1 (pskr1) (Matsubayashi et al., 2006, Mosher et al., 2013) or a references line with an EMS-induced mutation in Constitutive expression of PR genes 5 (cpr5) (Bowling et al., 1997), the reproductive success of Hpa isolate NoCo2 - measured as sporangiophore number per cotyledon or spore production - was significantly reduced compared to wild-type plants (Figure 1 a + c; Figure 1 – Figure Supplement 5).

caption.title: Mutations in A. thaliana CSGs reduce the reproductive success of the oomycetal downy mildew pathogen Hpa.
caption.p: (a + b) Bar charts represent the mean number of sporangiophores ± s.e.m on infected cotyledons of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the indicated mutants 4 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. (c) Bar charts represent the mean number of spores ± s.e.m per mg fresh weight isolated from A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the indicated mutants 4 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). Different letters indicate significant differences between groups (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction; p < 0.05).

sec.p: To capture potential structural or functional shifts during evolution, we included a range of NUP107-160 subcomplex members in our analysis that exceeded the list previously described as functionally relevant in the root symbioses of L. japonicus. The sec13 and nup133 single mutants and the sec13 x nup133 double mutant impaired Hpa reproductive success (Figure 1 a + c; Figure 1 – Figure Supplement 5), while lines with T-DNA insertions in nup43, nup85, nup160 and seh1 did not (Figure 1 b).

The reduced Hpa reproductive success could not be explained by a decreased frequency of haustoria formation measured as percentage of host cells contacted by hyphae that harbour an haustorium. Other than a slight decrease in pollux, the frequency in the other mutants was indistinguishable from the wild-type (Figure 1 – Figure Supplement 6).

However, all A. thaliana CSG mutants but not nup43, nup85, nup160 and seh1 mutants exhibited a significant shift in the ratio of haustoria morphologies (Figure 2; Figure 2 – Figure Supplement 3). At 5 days post infection (dpi) the majority of haustoria in leaves of the wild-type had a globular, single-lobed appearance. Deviations from such morphology, typically characterised by multiple lobes on a single haustorium (“multilobed”), were observed as well. The amount of multilobed haustoria in the CSG mutants was significantly increased, a phenomenon that was alleviated in the tested complementation lines (Figure 2 a + b; Figure 2 – Figure Supplement 1). Overexpression of L. japonicus SYMRK in the shrk1 x shrk2 double mutant resulted in a significant reduction of multilobed haustoria (Figure 2 a). In contrast to the CSG mutants, the disease resistant pskr1 mutant did not show any signs of altered haustoria development (Figure 2 a). In both, wild-type and shrk1 x shrk2, the percentage of multilobed haustoria increased over time, but was significantly higher in shrk1 x shrk2 at each analysed time point (Figure 2 d). To visualise the perihaustorial membrane in vivo, we made use of stable transgenic A. thaliana lines either expressing the N-terminally YFP-tagged remorin AtREM1.2 (At3g61260) under the control of its native promoter (pAt3g61260:YFP-At3g61260 (Jarsch et al., 2014)) or RPW8.2:YFP (Wang et. al., 2009) (Figure 2 – Figure Supplement 3 c + 4). We could confirm that multi-lobed haustoria appeared already in living plant cells and observed that the loss of YFP-AtREM1.2 fluorescence was associated with changes in haustoria morphology; while 49 - 68 % of the single-lobed haustoria exhibited YFP-AtREM1.2 fluorescence, only 14 – 19 % of the multi-lobed haustoria contained detectable amounts of YFP-AtREM1.2 at their perihaustorial membrane (Figure 2 – Figure Supplement 4).

caption.title: The morphology of Hpa haustoria is altered in A. thaliana CSG mutants.
caption.p: Boxplots represent the percentage of multilobed haustoria among total haustoria on A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0), the indicated mutants and transgenic complementation lines (pollux co, pPOLLUX:POLLUX; sec13 co, pSEC13:SEC13; shrk1 co, pUbi:ShRK1; shrk2 co, pUbi:ShRK2; LjSYMRK, pUbi:Lotus japonicus SYMRK-mOrange) 5 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2 (a + b), or 4, 5 and 7 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2 (d). (c) Representative pictures of intracellular haustoria are displayed. Bars = 25 µm. Black circles, data points outside 1.5 IQR of the upper/lower quartile; bold black line, median; box, IQR; whiskers, lowest/highest data point within 1.5 IQR of the lower/upper quartile. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). Different letters indicate significant differences between groups (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction; p < 0.05).

sec.p: L. japonicus SYMRK belongs to the LRR I-RLK family of receptor kinases, which consists of 50 members in A. thaliana (Shiu and Bleecker, 2003, Hok et al., 2011). Despite the large number of such RLKs in the A. thaliana genome, a detailed phenotypic analysis has only been published for Impaired Oomycete Susceptibility 1 (IOS1), which is involved in defence-related signalling (Chen et al., 2014, Hok et al., 2011). On the one hand, IOS1 supports the infection of an obligate biotrophic oomycetal pathogen, but on the other hand, is important for the resistance against bacteria (Chen et al., 2014, Hok et al., 2011). Interestingly, we could only observe altered haustoria morphology in an ios1 mutant of the A. thaliana ecotype Ler but not in an ios1 mutant of Col-0, which might imply that different paralogs are important for plant-microbe interaction in different ecotypes (Figure 2 – Figure Supplement 2).

To investigate the specificity of the role of CSGs in plant-pathogen interactions, we infected the CSG mutants with the haustoria-forming powdery mildew fungus E. cruciferarum. We did not observe a consistent reduction in the reproductive success of E. cruciferarum (Figure 1 – Figure Supplement 7). A morphological comparison of haustoria shape was not attempted because of the much more complex and highly variable haustoria morphology in this interaction.

Plant evolution resulted in several strategies to defend themselves against microbial pathogens. For example, PAMP triggered immunity (PTI) is triggered by the perception of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) or plant-derived damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) and results in plant defence responses accompanied by the activation of defence marker genes or callose deposition (Jones and Dangl, 2006; Antolin-Llovera et al., 2012; Gust et al., 2017). To analyse whether the increased Hpa resistance of the CSG mutants is a result of deregulated defence responses, we investigated the basal transcript levels of the three PAMP-induced marker genes - Pathogenesis-Related gene 1 (PR1), a marker gene for salicylic acid (SA)-mediated resistance (Ryals et al., 1996), Ethylene Response Factor 1 (ERF1), a marker gene for ethylene-mediated resistance (Solano et al., 1998) and the plant defensin PDF1.2a, a marker gene for jasmonic acid (JA)-and ethylene-mediated resistance (Penninckx et al., 1996) in the absence of pathogenic attack. Transcript levels in the tested mutants under non-challenged conditions did not differ from transcript levels in the wild-type (Figure 3 a, black circles). To examine whether CSG mutants show exacerbated activation of defence marker genes, we analysed the transcript levels of PR1, ERF1 and PDF1.2a in plants infected with Hpa. All tested genes were upregulated to a similar extend in the CSG mutants and the wild-type (Figure 3 a, empty circles). Only PDF1.2a transcript levels were significantly lower in Hpa-infected shrk1 x shrk2 plants than in infected wild-type plants, however, it is unlikely that this is the reason for the increased pathogen resistance of the double mutant. Moreover, the ability of Hpa to suppress callose deposition around the haustorial neck region (Sohn et al., 2007) was not disturbed in the CSG mutants compared to the wild-type (Figure 3 b).

caption.title: Activation of defence responses in response to Hpa infection is unaltered in A. thaliana CSG mutants.
caption.p: (a) Expression of PR1, ERF1 or PDF1.2a relative to the housekeeping genes TIP41-like and PP2A in mock-treated samples (black circles) or in Hpa-infected samples (empty circles) was determined in three biological replicates for each genotype by qPCR. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Dunnett’s Test with Bonferroni correction; *, p < 0.05). (b) Bar charts represent the mean intensity of callose deposition in leaves of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the indicated mutants 4 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. Circles, data points outside 1.5 IQR of the upper/lower quartile; bold black line, median; box, IQR; whiskers, lowest/highest data point within 1.5 IQR of the lower/upper quartile. No significant differences between Col-0 and the mutants or between any of the groups could be observed with a Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction or a Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction. Representative pictures of haustoria-associated callose deposition at the neck band of Hpa haustoria growing on the indicated mutants are shown on the right. Bars, 25 µm.

sec.p: In addition to the expression levels of defence marker genes, we investigated other symptoms typically associated with deregulated immune responses. We could not observe any developmental or growth defects, which are typically a result of the hyper-activation of the SA-dependent defence pathway (Bowling et al., 1997), in CSG mutants grown side-by-side with the wild-type and the dwarf mutant suppressor of npr1-1, constitutive 1 (snc1 (Li et al., 2001)) (Figure 3 – Figure Supplement 1). Furthermore, we analysed constitutive and Hpa-induced hypersensitive response (HR) in CSG mutants and the wild-type (Figure 3 – Figure Supplement 2). Most of the non-infected leaves did not display any sign of cell death (Figure 3 – Figure Supplement 2; first column), but dark-blue stained dead cells were sporadically observed with no significant differences between non-infected leaves of both wild-type and CSG mutants (Figure 3 – Figure Supplement 2; second column and upper graph). In infected leaves of the CSG mutants, cell death is detected in, or adjacent to, haustoria-containing cells in a frequency indistinguishable from or even lower than the wild-type (Figure 3 – Figure Supplement 2; third column and lower graph). In all genotypes, infected leaves contain hyphal strands growing in the absence of any cell death (Figure 3 – Figure Supplement 2; fourth column).

To examine whether mutations in CSGs have an effect on signalling related to PAMP-triggered immunity, we inspected the transcript levels of Flg22-induced Receptor-like Kinase 1 (FRK1 (Asai et al., 2002)) and ERF1 in the wild-type, the CSG mutants and a fls2 mutant (Figure 4 a) in response to the bacterial flagellin-derived peptide flg22 (Chinchilla et al., 2006). Transcript levels in mock-treated samples were not different in the wild-type and the analysed mutants, except for the shrk1 mutant that displayed a slight increase in basal FRK1 transcript levels, which was not detectable in the shrk1 x shrk2 double mutant, and the nup133 x sec13 double mutants that contained slightly decreased basal levels of ERF1 transcripts. The deviations observed for individual mutants are unlikely responsible for the increased Hpa resistance. Six hours after flg22 treatment the tested genes were all upregulated to the same extend in the CSG mutants and the wild-type (Figure 4 a). Furthermore, we investigated the growth behaviour of P. syringae on the wild-type and on CSG mutants (Figure 4 b). P. syringae pv. tomato (Pto) DC3000 induces the activation of SA-dependent defence signalling in the host, and deregulation of this pathways impairs P. syringae resistance (Glazebrook, 2005). The growth of Pto DC3000 wild-type or the avirulent ΔAvrPto/PtoB strain was unaltered on the A. thaliana CSG mutants, providing further evidence that they do not exhibit constitutive or enhanced activation of SA-dependent defences (Figure 4 b).

caption.title: Expression of flg22-inducible genes as well as growth of the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae are not affected in A. thaliana CSG mutants.
caption.p: (a) Expression of FRK1 and ERF1 relative to the housekeeping genes TIP41-like and PP2A in mock-treated samples (black circles) or in flg22-treated samples (empty circles) was determined in three biological replicates for each genotype by qPCR. The fls2 mutant served as negative control. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Dunnett’s Test with Bonferroni correction; *, p < 0.01; **, p < 0.001). (b) Bacterial density of Pto DC3000 or Pto DC3000 ΔAvrPto/PtoB on A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the indicated mutants was determined as colony forming units per cm2 2 dpi. Data represent means ± s.d. of six replicate measurements/genotype/data point. Results from one representative of at least four independent experiments are shown.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Biotrophic hyphal pathogens depend on the vitality of their host cell for their own survival and reproduction because they frequently form intracellular feeding structures called haustoria. The developmental programs of the host that are supporting intracellular accommodation of haustoria are largely unexplored. Moreover, plant genes that are involved in the subcellular reprogramming of the host required for haustoria formation are largely unknown. Here we explored the hypothesis that the biotrophic pathogen Hpa exploits an ancestral pathway - defined by the so called common symbiosis genes (CSG) - that enabled intracellular accommodation in the context of arbuscular mycorrhiza and the nitrogen-fixing root nodule symbiosis.

sec.title: CSG mutants reveal a link between the timing of haustorial shape shifts and reproductive success
sec.p: We observed - based on sporangiophore and spore counts - that A. thaliana CSG mutants are impaired in supporting the reproduction of the oomycetal pathogen Hpa. This was associated with a shift in the haustoria morphology. While the frequency of multilobed haustoria increased in the wild-type as well as in the mutants over time, it was significantly higher in the A. thaliana CSG mutants at all time points analysed. This finding reveals a connection between haustoria morphology and the age of the interaction and suggests that haustoria aging is accelerated in the CSG mutants. It remains unclear whether single-lobed haustoria develop into multilobed haustoria over time, or whether in older interactions multilobed haustoria form directly, without a single lobed intermediate step. The presence of REM1.2 at the peri-haustorial membrane was strongly decreased around multilobed haustoria, indicating an age-related alteration of the protein composition of the perihaustorial membrane. It has been postulated that haustoria are the main avenue for nutrient acquisition from the host (Voegele, R. T. and Mendgen, K., 2003). Senescence of haustoria is associated with encasement and thus is likely to reduce their functionality (Caillaud et al., 2014). Therefore, it is likely that the premature formation of multilobed haustoria might be directly responsible for the reduction in Hpa reproductive success. Taken together our results suggest a role of Arabidopsis CSG genes in maintaining the single lobed, and presumably functional, stage of Hpa haustoria.

sec.title: CSG mutants exhibit no traces of altered plant defence responses or regulation
sec.p: In order to determine whether plant defence responses caused the reduction of the Hpa reproductive success, we quantified a range of defence symptoms in the wild-type and the mutants. Based on these analyses, we could rule out a constitutively or exacerbated activation of PTI signature marker genes. Furthermore, we did not detect an increased frequency of cell death, a symptom of defence-related hypersensitive responses. This is in accordance with the identical bacterial density reached in CSG mutants and the wild type. In summary, based on the analysis of a wide range of defence symptoms in the classical PTI assays and three different pathosystems, we conclude that A. thaliana CSG mutants display unaltered levels and frequencies of defence responses. Consequentially, the impairment of the Hpa interaction is not due to deregulated defence in these mutants.

sec.title: Arabidopsis CSG mutants are specifically impaired in the Hpa interaction
sec.p: We were unable to detect differences in the interaction of A. thaliana CSG mutants with the haustoria-forming powdery mildew fungus E. cruciferarum in comparison to wild-type plants. This may be due to the different cell types targeted by Hpa and E. cruciferarum for haustoria formation. Hpa infects the epidermal cells and then progresses to the mesophyll (Slusarenko and Schlaich, 2003) in which the vast majority of haustoria are formed, while E. cruciferarum forms haustoria directly within epidermal cells (Micali et al., 2008). Cell-type specific functionality has been described for the CSGs under study (Hayashi et al., 2014, Bensmihen et al., 2011). In addition, the genetic requirements for the intracellular accommodation of fungal and oomycetal pathogens may differ. The A. thaliana Mildew resistance Locus O (MLO) gene, for instance, is an epidermal compatibility factor required for powdery mildew fungus penetration (Consonni et al., 2006), with no role in the Hpa interaction reported to date. However, it should be noted that the haustoria of E. cruciferarum are structurally very complex and irregularly shaped. Because of this inherent polymorphy, it is possible that we missed subtle structural changes caused by the CSG mutations.

sec.title: Functional conservation of common symbiosis gene homologs between A. thaliana and L. japonicus
sec.p: Intriguingly, transgenic complementation of a symbiosis-defective legume mutant with versions of the A. thaliana homolog of POLLUX indicates overall functional conservation (Venkateshwaran et al., 2012).

Likewise, successful restoration of the Hpa haustoria development in the A. thaliana shrk1 x shrk 2 double mutant by the legume SYMRK gene (Figure 2 a) indicates conservation of this functional feature despite loss of the actual SYMRK ortholog in the A. thaliana genome.

Despite of the critical cellular function of the nuclear pore complex for import and export, legume mutants defective in certain members of the nucleoporin subcomplex 107-160 are specifically defective in symbiosis with rhizobia and AM fungi, but otherwise largely free of macroscopically detectable phenotypes. We could confirm that also in A. thaliana, the overall size, shape and development of NUP107-160 complex mutants are macroscopically wild-type-like (Figure 3 – Figure Supplement 1). Several nucleoporins of the NUP107-160 subcomplex show a high rate of evolution (Bapteste et al., 2005), share similar structures and are therefore potentially able to replace each other, potentially allowing for distinct functional adaptations while keeping the overall complex structure intact (Binder and Parniske, 2013b). Agreeing with this, phenotypes of individual NUP107-160 subcomplex mutants vary both in occurrence and severity depending on the organism (Gonzalez-Aguilera and Askjaer, 2012, Binder and Parniske, 2013a). To capture potential structural or functional evolutionary shifts, we included more NUP107-160 subcomplex members than those previously described as functionally relevant for legume root symbioses. Interestingly, we found that the sec13 and nup133 single mutants and the sec13 x nup133 double mutant are impaired in the interaction with Hpa, while the nup43, nup85, nup160 and seh1 single mutants are not. This pattern is not 100% congruent with the observation in the legume L. japonicus, in which seh1, nup85 and nup133 impaired symbiosis (Kanamori et al., 2006, Saito et al., 2007, Groth et al., 2010), however, it clearly sheds light on a specific role of this subcomplex for the root symbioses of legumes and the Hpa interaction of A. thaliana. The differences in the specific subcomplex members that reveal a phenotype may be explained by clade-specific adaptations of the NUP107-160 subcomplex. Furthermore, the NUP107-160 subcomplex has been implicated in plant defence; mutations in NUP96, NUP160 and SEH1 impair basal and resistance-gene mediated immunity (Zhang and Li, 2005, Wiermer et al., 2012). However, A. thaliana CSG nucleoporin mutants did not show such deregulation (Figure 3 + 4), possibly due to distinct roles of individual subcomplex components in compatibility and defence.

sec.title: Genetic overlaps between symbiotic and pathogen biotrophic interactions
sec.p: It is a long-standing hypothesis that plant pathogens exploit genetic pathways for the intracellular accommodation of mutualistic symbionts such as AM fungi or nitrogen-fixing bacteria (Parniske et al., 2000). Supporting this hypothesis, it has been reported that several genetic components important for mutualistic plant-microbe interactions are as well supporting the interaction of plant roots and filamentous pathogens (Wang et al., 2012, Rey et al., 2013, Rey et al., 2014).

The glycerol-phosphate acyl-transferase gene RAM2 for example, is important for the successful colonisation of Medicago truncatula by the oomycetal pathogen Phytophthora palmivora, but it also plays a role in the development of AM fungal hyphopodia and arbuscules during AM symbiosis (Wang et al., 2012). This observation implies that a compatibility factor can be exploited by microbial pathogens and, likewise, by beneficial symbionts. In contrast to our findings, in the ram2 mutant, the interaction with P. palmivora was already impaired at the stage of appressoria formation (Wang et al., 2012).

In the present study, we were able to demonstrate genetic commonalities of symbiosis and disease in the formation and maintenance of intracellular accommodation structures at a later developmental stage of the plant-microbe association. Although strongly suggested by the function of the CSGs, it remains unclear whether their A. thaliana homologs are similarly involved in a signal transduction pathway directly supporting oomycetal development. It will be therefore interesting to identify the mechanistic commonalities between symbiotic and pathogenic interactions that are controlled by the CSGs.

sec.title: Loss of AM but retention of CSGs
sec.p: The loss of AM symbiosis in A. thaliana and in four other independent plant lineages was correlated with the absence of more than 100 genes with potential roles in AM (Delaux et al., 2013, Favre et al., 2014, Delaux et al., 2014, Bravo et al., 2016). The requirement of CSGs for full Hpa reproductive success indicates that, like in ram2, pathogens exploit the ancient symbiotic program, and the selection pressure resulting from this scenario provides a plausible explanation for the observed convergent pattern of symbiosis-related gene loss.

sec.title: Hpa, a secret mutualist?
sec.p: While the exploitation of symbiotic programs by pathogens might explain the consistent deletion of CSGs from five independent plant lineages, it raises the question, which evolutionary forces retained certain CSGs in an otherwise AM-asymbiotic plant. A housekeeping function was not revealed since no pleiotropic developmental phenotypes were observed in the mutants. This leaves us with the unexpected finding that the only detected role for the CSGs in A. thaliana is the support of an oomycete. It will be interesting to find out whether ecological conditions exist, under which oomycetal colonization might provide a selective advantage to the host plant (Salvaudon et al., 2008).

sec.title: Seed sterilization and plant growth
sec.p: All A. thaliana mutants described in the manuscript were of Col-0 ecotype, except for ios1, which was either of Col-0 or Ler ecotype. Seeds were obtained from “The Nottingham Arabidopsis Stock Centre” – NASC (Scholl et al., 2000) or the GABI-DUPLO double mutant collection (Bolle et al., 2013). For in vitro experiments, A. thaliana seeds were sterilized by incubation for 5 min in sterilisation solution (70 % ethanol, 0.05 % Tween20), followed by incubation for 2 min in 100 % ethanol. For Hpa infection, seeds were directly germinated in soil and grown for two weeks under long day conditions (16 h light, 22 °C, 85 µmol m-2 s-1). For E. cruciferarum inoculation, plants were grown in a 2:1 soil/sand mixture. Seeds were stratified for 48 h at 4 °C prior to transfer into a growth chamber (10 h light, 120 μmol m−2 s−1 light, 22 °C day, 20 °C night, 65% relative humidity). For elicitor treatment, seeds were placed on half-strength MS plates (Murashige and Skoog, 1962), stratified for 48 h at 4 °C in the dark, and grown for 8 days under long day conditions (16 h light, 23 °C, 85 µmol m-2 s-1).

sec.title: A. thaliana stable transformation
sec.p: To transform A. thaliana, flowers were dipped in Agrobacterium suspensions as described previously (Clough and Bent, 1998).

sec.title: Pathogen assays and phenotypic analyses
sec.p: Seven days after infection, A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0 or Ler) leaves with sporulating Hpa isolate NoCo2 or Hpa isolate Waco9, respectively, were harvested into 15 mL reaction tubes containing 10 mL dH2O and vortexed for 2 s. The spore solution was then filtered through a Miracloth filter and sprayed onto 12-days-old plants using a spraying device. Subsequently, plants were placed into trays and covered with wet translucid lids. Trays were sealed to maintain high humidity, and plants were grown under long day conditions (16 h light, 18 °C, 85 µmol m-2s-1).

For spore counting, A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) and mutant seedlings were harvested five days after infection. Ten seedlings per background were harvested into reaction tubes containing 1 mL dH2O and vortexed for 3 min. The spore solution was then filtered through a Miracloth filter and spores were counted with a Fuchs Rosenthal chamber.

Cotyledons or leaves were harvested and stained in 0.01 % trypan-blue-lactophenol (10 mL lactic acid, 10 mL glycerol, 10 g phenol, 10 mg trypan blue dissolved in 10 mL distilled water) for 3 min at 95°C and 5 h at room temperature, followed by overnight clearing in saturated chloral hydrate (2.5 g/mL). For observation using differential interference contrast microscopy, samples were mounted in glycerol. For sporangiophore counting, a minimum of 50 cotyledons per genotype and replicate were analysed and the number of sporangiophores per infected cotyledon was plotted. For investigation of haustoria shape and penetration efficiency, a minimum of five leaves per genotype and replicate were analysed. On each leaf, the percentage of multilobed haustoria per total haustoria or the percentage of haustoria-containing cells per cells contacted by hyphae was calculated for 10 individual strands of hyphae. The mean for each leaf was calculated and plotted.

E. cruciferarum was grown on A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) to maintain aggressiveness and on susceptible phytoalexin deficient 4 (pad4) mutants (Glazebrook et al., 1996) for elevated conidia production. Plants were placed under a polyamide net (0.2 mm2) and inoculated at a density of 3 – 4 conidia mm−2, by brushing conidia off of pad4 mutant leaves through the net. Two leaves per plant were harvested, cleared and kept in acetic acid (25 %) until microscopic analysis. Leaves were stained in acetic acid (25 %) ink (1:9) (Königsblau, Pelikan, 4001), washed in water, placed in water containing a few drops of Tween20, washed in water again, and analysed under a bright-field microscope. For each replicate, conidiophores per colony were counted on 10 colonies per leaf, on 5 - 10 leaves per genotype.

Bacterial strains Pto DC3000 or Pto DC3000 ΔAvrPto/AvrPto were grown and used for infection assays on leaves of 4 – 5 weeks old A. thaliana plants as described previously (Lin and Martin, 2005, Kemmerling et al., 2007).
Each experiment was performed at least three times independently.

sec.title: Observation of haustoria
sec.p: For morphology analysis of haustoria, leaves of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the shrk1 x shrk2 double mutant were harvested at 5 dpi, cleared in 10 M KOH for 5 min, stained with 0.05 % aniline blue in 0.067 M K2HPO4 for 20 min and observed with a confocal light scanning microscope (Leica SP5; excitation at 360-380 nm, detection at 470-505 nm). Images were edited using ImageJ with the “volume viewer” plugin (Schneider et al., 2012).

For the Technovit section, leaves of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or CSG mutants were infected with Hpa as described above and harvested at 7 dpi. Leaves were fixed by 3.7% formaldehyde and followed by a serial dehydration process by incubating samples in 30%, 50%, 70% and 100% ethanol. Samples were than incubated in the mixture of Technovit 7100 solution A (100 ml Technovit 7100, 1 pack Hardener 1, 2.5 ml PEG 4000) with ethanol in different proportion (solution A: 100% ethanol= 1:3, solution A: 100% ethanol= 1:1 and solution A: 100% ethanol= 3:1 each for 30 min, followed by solution A overnight). After the incubation, samples were mounted in the polymerization solution (15 ml solution A, 1 ml Hardener II) then held by the mount holders (10 ml Technovit 3040 and 5 ml universal liquid). Sections were made by LEICA RM2125RT for 7 μm thick. Technovit sections were than stained with 0.01 % trypan-blue-lactophenol solution, which described above, at 37 °C for at least 3 hr, until the sections turned blue. Then distained samples gently with a drop of chloral hydrate (2.5 g/mL) and rinsed by water. Technovit sections were observed under LEICA DMI 6000B microscope.

For quantification of fluorescence associated with the perihaustorial membrane, A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) plants transformed with the construct pAt3g61260:YFP-At3g61260 were infected with Hpa as described above, harvested at 8 dpi and observed with a microscope using differential interference contrast or epifluorescence microscopy with YFP filter settings (Leica DMI6000B; excitation at 500/20, emission at 535/30). The quantification was performed in triplicates. For each biological replicate consisting of 6 leaves, 100 single-lobed and 100 multilobed haustoria were counted and scored for detectable fluorescence. Haustoria without detectable fluorescence were visualized by differential interference contrast microscopy and scored as non-fluorescent.

A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) plants expressing RPW8.2:YFP (Wang et. al., 2009) were infected with Hpa as described above, harvested at 10 dpi and observed with a confocal microscope with an Argon 488-nm laser exciter (Leica TCS SP5 confocal; excitation at 520, emission at 560) under ×63 NA 1.2 water-immersion lenses (Carl Zeiss Inc., Thornwood, NY, U.S.A.).

sec.title: Analysis of oomycete-associated callose deposition
sec.p: Oomycete-associated callose deposition was analysed on cotyledons of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or CSG mutants. Leaves were harvested at 4 dpi, cleared in 10 M KOH for 5 min, stained with 0.05 % aniline blue in 0.067 M K2HPO4 for 20 min and mounted in glycerol for observation with an epifluorescence microscope with CFP filter settings (Leica DMI6000B; excitation 436/10, emission 465/30). Regions of interest (ROIs) covering the neck bands were selected in ImageJ(Schneider et al., 2012) and the signal intensity of each neck band was calculated from single ROIs and mean intensities were plotted. n = 27 – 72.

sec.title: Elicitor treatment
sec.p: For pre-incubation, 8 days old seedlings were transferred to a 12-well plate (3 seedlings/well represent one biological replicate) with half-strength liquid MS medium (Murashige and Skoog, 1962) supplemented with 1 % sucrose and incubated overnight under long-day conditions (16 h light, 22 °C, 100 µmol m-2 s-1; 8 h dark, 18 °C) and 100 rpm shaking. On the following day the medium was exchanged, half of the samples were supplemented with 1 µM flg22, and the other half was kept in half-strength MS to serve as mock controls. Plants were then incubated for 6 h at 22 °C and 100 rpm shaking. For every genotype, three biological replicates of treated and non-treated samples were harvested and immediately frozen in liquid N2 for subsequent RNA extraction.

sec.title: RNA Extraction and qPCR analysis
sec.p: RNA extraction was performed using the SpectrumTM Plant Total RNA kit (Sigma-Aldrich), followed by DNase I treatment (amplification grade DNase I, InvitrogenTM) to remove genomic DNA. First strand cDNA synthesis was performed from 250 ng total RNA using the SuperScript® III First-Strand Synthesis SuperMix (InvitrogenTM) with oligo(dT) primers. qPCR was performed in 20 µL reactions containing 1x SYBR Green I (InvitrogenTM) in a CFX96 Real-time PCR detection system (Bio-Rad). PCR program: 2’-95°C; 40 x (30’’-95°C; 30’’-60°C; 20’’-72°C); melting curve 95°C – 60°C – 95°C. A primer list can be found in the supplemental material. Expression levels of target genes were normalized against the housekeeping genes TIP41-like and PP2A (Czechowski et al., 2005). For every genotype, three biological replicates and two technical duplicates were analysed.

sec.title: Gene structure and phylogenetic analyses
sec.p: Complete annotated genomic sequences were obtained from The Arabidopsis Information Resource (TAIR – www.arabidopsis.org) for A. thaliana, and from the KDRI website (Kazusa DNA Research Institute, Japan; http://www.kazusa.or.jp/lotus/) and the GenBank for L. japonicus. BLAST searches were performed on TAIR (http://arabidopsis.org/Blast/index.jsp) with the L. japonicus genomic CSG sequences as query. The protein domain organization and the exon-intron structure of the A. thaliana homologs of POLLUX, SEC13, NUP133 (GenBank accession number: KM269292), ShRK1 and ShRK2 are identical to that of their L. japonicus counterparts. By sequencing a PCR product amplified from A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) cDNA, we demonstrated that, contrary to the TAIR prediction, this was also the case for NUP133. The curated sequence has been submitted to TAIR.

For phylogenetic studies, protein sequences of A. thaliana and L. japonicus MLD-LRR-RLKs were aligned using MAFFT 7 (Kuraku et al., 2013, Katoh et al., 2017) with default settings. Alignments were used to create phylogenetic trees at the CIPRES web-portal with RAxML 8.2.10 (Stamatakis et al., 2008) for maximum likelihood analyses. For RAxML, the JTT PAM matrix for amino acid substitutions was chosen, and the GTRGAMMA model was used for both bootstrapping and tree inference.

sec.title: Statistics and data visualisation
sec.p: All statistical analyses and data plots have been performed and generated with R version 3.0.2 (2013-09-25) “Frisbee Sailing”(Team, 2013) using the packages “Hmisc”(Harrell, 2014) “car”(Fox, 2011), “multcompView”(Graves et al., 2012) and “multcomp”(Hothorn et al., 2008) or Excel. For statistical analysis, data was either subjected to the nonparametric Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction using Col-0 samples as control group, or to the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction comparing every group with each other, or was power transformed to improve normality and a one-way ANOVA followed by a Dunnett’s Test with Bonferroni correction was performed using Col-0 samples as control group.

ack.p: This work was supported by grants from the German Research Foundation (DFG) and the European Research Commission (ERC) to MP. We thank Birgit Kemmerling for kindly sending us pskr-1 seeds, Thomas Ott for providing pAt3g61260:YFP-At3g61260 seeds, Dirk Metzler for help with statistical analyses and Rosa Elena Andrade Aguirre for help with the phylogenetic analyses.

sec.p: MKR, ABa, ABi, AAG, CH, RH, TN, MP conceived the research and designed the experiments, ABa, MKR, ABi, FYH, AAG, CH performed the experiments, MKR, ABa, MP wrote the manuscript.

sec.p: The authors declare no conflict of interests.

caption.title: Comparison of gene structures and protein domains of L. japonicus CSGs and their closest homologs in A. thaliana.
caption.p: TAIR/GenBank protein identifiers are shown; dashed lines, positions of introns in the original gene sequence; red triangles, positions of T-DNA insertion in the respective mutants; SP, signal peptide; MLD, malectin-like domain; LRRs, leucine-rich repeats; TM, transmembrane domain; KD, kinase domain.

caption.title: A. thaliana CSGs with encoded proteins and their respective identities / similarities to their L. japonicus homologs.
caption.p: Sequence identifiers and identities / similarities shared between the protein sequences of A. thaliana CSGs and those of their respective L. japonicus counterparts. The numbers for AtSEC13 indicate the identity / similarity of its amino acid sequence to each of the two predicted LjSEC13 proteins. For ShRK1 and ShRK2, numbers in brackets refer to their kinase domain (KD) only. n.d., not detected. NASC ID: insertion mutant identifier.

caption.title: Maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree of the extracytoplasmic domains of MLD-LRR-RLKs from A. thaliana and L. japonicus SYMRK.
caption.p: The specific domain composition featuring a MLD followed by the conserved gly-asp-pro-cys (GDPC) motif known to be required for the proper establishment of the symbiotic program in the root epidermis (Kosuta et al., 2011, Antolin-Llovera et al., 2014), and LRRs is not restricted to SYMRK but can also be found in 42 of the 50 members of LRR I-RLKs present in A. thaliana, where this family underwent a recent expansion (Shiu and Bleecker, 2003, Hok et al., 2011). A maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree based on the extracytoplasmic regions (excluding the signal peptides) of 42 MLD-LRR-RLK proteins from A. thaliana and SYMRK from L. japonicus. Numbers on each node represent the respective bootstrap values. Bar, relative genetic distance (arbitrary unit).

caption.title: Maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree of the highly conserved kinase domains of MLD-LRR-RLKs from A. thaliana and L. japonicus SYMRK.
caption.p: A maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree based on the highly conserved kinase domains of 42 MLD-LRR-RLK proteins from A. thaliana and SYMRK from L. japonicus. Numbers on each node represent the respective bootstrap values. Bar, relative genetic distance (arbitrary unit).

caption.title: Mutations in A. thaliana CSGs reduce the reproductive success of the oomycetal downy mildew pathogen H. arabidopsidis.
caption.p: Bar charts represent the mean number of sporangiophores ± s.e.m on infected cotyledons of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the indicated mutants 4 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2 in two additional replicates (a + b). Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). Different letters indicate significant differences between groups (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction).

caption.title: Mutations in A. thaliana CSGs do not reduce the number of cells that accommodate haustoria.
caption.p: Boxplots represent the percentage of haustoria-containing cells per cells contacted by hyphae on leaves of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0), the indicated mutants and the transgenic complementation lines (pollux co, pPOLLUX:POLLUX) 5 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. Black circles, data points outside 1.5 IQR of the upper/lower quartile; bold black line, median; box, IQR; whiskers, lowest/highest data point within 1.5 IQR of the lower/upper quartile. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). Different letters indicate significant differences between groups (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction)

caption.title: Mutations in A. thaliana CSGs do not impair the reproductive success of the fungal powdery mildew pathogen E. cruciferarum.
caption.p: Bar charts represent the mean number of conidiophores ± s.e.m on leaves of the indicated mutants relative to the wild-type (Col-0) 5 dpi with E. cruciferarum for three independent replicates. No significant differences to Col-0 were detected (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). No significant differences between groups were detected (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction; p < 0.05).

caption.title: The morphology of Hpa haustoria is altered in A. thaliana CSG mutants.
caption.p: Boxplots represent the percentage of multilobed haustoria among total haustoria on A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the indicated mutants 5 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. Black circles, data points outside 1.5 IQR of the upper/lower quartile; bold black line, median; box, IQR; whiskers, lowest/highest data point within 1.5 IQR of the lower/upper quartile. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). Different letters indicate significant differences between groups (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction).

caption.title: The morphology of Hpa haustoria is only altered in a A. thaliana ios1 mutant in the Ler background.
caption.p: Boxplots represent the percentage of multilobed haustoria among total haustoria on A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0; Ler), and ios1 mutant lines 5 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2 (a), 5 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2 and Waco9. Black circles, data points outside 1.5 IQR of the upper/lower quartile; bold black line, median; box, IQR; whiskers, lowest/highest data point within 1.5 IQR of the lower/upper quartile. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). Different letters indicate significant differences between groups (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction; p < 0.05).

caption.title: The morphology of Hpa haustoria is altered in A. thaliana CSG mutants.
caption.p: (a) Light microscopy of Technovit section of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the shrk1 x shrk2 double mutant 7 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. Bars, 10 µm. (b) Confocal light scanning microscopy of leaves of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the shrk1 x shrk2 double mutant stained with aniline-blue 5 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. For every haustorium, the entry point can be identified by the formation of the usually bright callose neck. Bars, 25 µm. (c) Confocal light scanning microscopy of leaves of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) expressing RPW8.2:YFP, which localises to the perihaustorial membrane. *, round haustoria; +, multilobed haustoria; arrows, hyphae. Bars, 10 μm.

caption.title: Quantification of haustoria with a fluorescent perihaustorial membrane on A. thaliana plants expressing YFP-AtREM1.2.
caption.p: (a) A. thaliana plants expressing N-terminally YFP-tagged AtREM1.2 under the control of its native promoter were inspected with an epifluorescence microscope 8 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. Representative pictures of YFP-positive and YFP-negative (completely dark) haustoria are shown. Yellow dashed lines delimitate haustoria in the bright field images. Bars, 25 µM. (b) Graph represents the percentage of fluorescent haustoria as a function of morphology (1st replicate, 49 % of single-lobed haustoria show fluorescence/19 % of multilobed haustoria show fluorescence; 2nd replicate, 56 % single-lobed/17 % multilobed, 3rd replicate: 68 % single-lobed/14 % multilobed).

caption.title: A. thaliana CSG mutants do not show developmental or growth defects.
caption.p: 3-week-old A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) plants grown alongside the indicated mutant lines under long day conditions. The dwarf phenotype of snc1 is included on the far right for comparison.

caption.title: Levels of spontaneous or pathogen-induced cell death are unaltered in A. thaliana CSG mutants.
caption.p: Differential interference contrast microscopy of A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) and CSG mutant leaves stained with trypan-blue lactophenol 4 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. First column, non-infected without cell death; second column, non-infected with random cell death; third column, infected with cell death in, or adjacent to, haustoria-containing cells; fourth column, infected without cell death. Bars, 25 µm. Boxplots represent the number of random (upper graph) or Hpa-associated (lower graph) cell death spots per leaf on A. thaliana wild-type (Col-0) or the indicated mutants 5 dpi with Hpa isolate NoCo2. Circles, data points outside 1.5 IQR of the upper/lower quartile; bold black line, median; box, IQR; whiskers, lowest/highest data point within 1.5 IQR of the lower/upper quartile. Stars indicate significant differences to Col-0 (Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test with Bonferroni-Holm correction; *, p < 0.05; **, p < 0.01; ***, p < 0.001). Different letters indicate significant differences between groups (Kruskal-Wallis test with Bonferroni correction; p < 0.05).
